data.title: Philosophy
data.meta_description: Philosophers of the Ancient Greek World: A Hellenic Electronic Center Project
data.text:
Philosophers List

Acrion (5th / 4th century BC)

Acrion was a philosopher born in Locri, a town in Calabria, Italy, whose learning was a part of the Pythagorean Philosophy.

Adrastus of Aphrodisias - á¼Î´ÏÎ±ÏÏÎ¿Ï (2nd century AD)

Adrastus was from an ancient Greek city called Aphrodisias, located within historic Caria in western Asia Minor, who was known as a Peripatetic philosopher.

Aedesia - Îá¼°Î´ÎµÏÎ¯Î± (5th century)

Aedesia was born in Alexandria and lived there for most of her life.Â She was a part of the Neoplatonic School and was known for her intelligence and beauty. She accompanied her children to Athens where they too were educated in the field of philosophy.

Aedesius - Îá¼°Î´Î­ÏÎ¹Î¿Ï (3rd / 4th century)

Aedesius was born in Cappadocia, but settled in Syria where he apprenticed.Â As a Neo-Platonist, his concentration was in mysticism. Â Later in his life, he founded a school of philosophy at Pergamon in Asia Minor, near the Aegean Sea coastline.

Aeneas of Gaza (5th / 6th century)

Aeneas was born in Gaza.Â He was a Neo-Platonic philosopher and a convert to Christianity.Â Christianity influenced his work, of which Theophrastus is his most well-known dialogue.

Aenesidemus - Îá¼°Î½Î·ÏÎ¯Î´Î·Î¼Î¿Ï (1st century BC?)

Aenesidemus was born in Knossos, an archaeological site near Heraklion, Crete.Â He founded the Third Sceptic School also known as Pyrrhonism .Â Rumoured to have been a memberÂ of Plato`sÂ Academy, he became known by breaking from Platonic theories and reviving the principle of epochÃ© (ÎµÏÎ¿ÏÎ®). The Pyrrhoneia (Î Ï ÏÏÏÎ½ÎµÎ¹Î¿Î¹ Î»Ã³Î³Î¿Î¹) is the main work for which he is known and in which are discussed four ideas: the reasons for scepticism and doubt , arguments against causality and truth , a physical theory, and an ethical theory .

Aesara -Â Îá¼°ÏÎ¬ÏÎ± (5th / 4th century BC)

Aesara was a woman philosopher born in the ancient district of Lucania (ÎÎµÏ ÎºÎ±Î½Î¯Î±), in Southern Italy.Â With little known about her life, Stobaeus preserved a part of her philosophical work entitled On Human Nature. Her learning appears to be of Pythagorean influence.

Aeschines of Neapolis â Îá¼°ÏÏÎ¯Î½Î·Ï (2nd / 1st century BC)

Aeschines was born in Neapolis, what is today Naples, Italy. The etymology of the city name Neapolis refers to the founding of a ânew townâ and this city name is prevalent in many ancient cities of the Hellenistic world.Â The Academy of Athens at about 110 BC was known to have had three leaders.Â Aeschines was one of these leaders along with Charmadas and Clitomachus.Â His learning is a part of Platonism and more preciselyÂ that of Academic skepticism .

Aeschines of Sphettus - Îá¼°ÏÏÎ¯Î½Î·Ï Î£ÏÎ®ÏÏÎ¹Î¿ÏÂ (5th / 4th century BC)

Aeschines belonged to the deme (Î´á¿Î¼Î¿Ï) Sphettus, a suburb of Athens, by the birth right of his father Lysanias.Â In his youth, Lysanias was a follower of Socrates.Â Aeschines became known as Aeschines Socraticus.Â After the death of Socrates, Aeschines wrote philosophical dialogues in which Socrates had the main role.Â Plato also wrote these kind of dialogues. As Dioegenus LaÃ«rtius reported, Aeschines wrote seven Socratic dialogues: Alcibiades, Aspasia, Axiochus, Callias, Miltiades, Rhinon, Telauges .

Aetius of Antioch - á¼Î­ÏÎ¹Î¿Ï á½ á¼Î½ÏÎ¹Î¿ÏÎµÏÏ (4th century AD)

Aetius of Antioch was from the Coele (ÎÎ¿Î¯Î»Î·), Syria, which is a Syrian region in classical antiquity.Â His childhood was marked by poverty or slavery, later becoming a goldsmith in Antioch. He studied philosophy, Christian scriptures, Christian theology, and medicine in Alexandria.Â Known for debating with other philosophers of Christian Doctrine, he earned the derogatory nickname of âThe Atheistâ, by the pro-Trinitarian representatives.Â The Trinitarian representatives learned about God as a Trinity â Father, Son and Holy Spirit. Aetius, however, believed that the idea of the homoousia of trinity is self-contradictory; thus, becoming the leader for the Anomoean sect.

Agapius - á¼Î³Î¬ÏÎ¹Î¿Ï (5th / 6th century AD)

Agapius was from Athens where he also was a part of the Neo-Platonist School.

Agathobulus â Agathoboulos Â (1st / 2nd century AD)

Agathobulus was from Alexandria and known as a Cynic philosopher.Â Reportedly, Agathobulus taught a training in asceticism

Agathosthenes - á¼Î³Î±Î¸Î¿ÏÎ¸Î­Î½Î·Ï

Agathosthenes became known by ancient writers who referred to his work.Â There are no reliable data on him, other than the fact that he was Greek philosopher, historian and geographer. There is mention of his work âAsiatica Carminaâ and his work on the history of the island of Naxos.

Agrippa the Skeptic - á¼Î³ÏÎ¯ÏÏÎ±Ï (1st / 2nd century AD)

Agrippa was the one of the most famous Skeptic philosophers. The author of Five Grounds of Doubt, âtropesâ (ÏÏÏÏÎ¿Î¹), he proves with this work the impossibility of true or certain knowledge: dissent, progress ad infinitum, relation, assumption, circularity.

Albinus â á¼Î»Î²á¿Î½Î¿Ï (2nd century AD)

Albinus was from Smyrna, an Ancient Greek city on the Aegean coast of Asia Minor.Â He was a Platonist and he is known as the author of a short tract called âIntroduction to Platoâs Dialoguesâ. Furthermore , Albinus was quoted by other philosophers who wrote in Latin on music and geometry.

Alcinous â á¼Î»ÎºÎ¯Î½Î¿Ï Ï (2nd century AD?)

Alcinous was a Middle Platonist philosopher.Â Little is known about his life. He is the author of a significant work intended for teachers entitled â The Handbook of Platonism ( á¼ ÏÎ¹ÏÎ¿Î¼ á½´ Ï á¿¶ Î½ Î Î»Î¬ÏÏÎ½Î¿Ï Î´Î¿Î³Î¼Î¬ÏÏÎ½ )â, containing 36 chapters dedicated to a variety of subjects ranging from logic and ethics to physics.

Alcmaeon of Croton - á¼Î»ÎºÎ¼Î±Î¯ÏÎ½ (5th / 5th century BC)

Alcmaeon was born in the ancient city of Crotone in the region of Calabria, Southern Italy, known as Magna Graecia. Being a Pythagorean, he counts among the most significant natural philosophers (ÏÏ ÏÎ¹Îºá½¸Î½ Î»ÏÎ³Î¿Î½) and theorists of medicine. His concentration was the philosophy of science, including astrology and meteorology.Â The thoroughness of his work led him to be the first to identify the Eustachian Tubes.

Alexamenus of Teos - Î¤Î®Î¹Î¿Ï á¼Î»ÎµÎ¾Î±Î¼ÎµÎ½ÏÏ (5th century BC?)

Alexamenus was from Teos â Î¤Î­ÏÏ, an ancient Greek city in Asia Minor along the coastline of the Aegean Sea.Â The most significant moment in his life is that he is the first person who wrote Socratic dialogues before the time of Plato.

Alexander of Aegae - á¼Î»Î­Î¾Î±Î½Î´ÏÎ¿Ï (1st century AD)

Alexander was from the archaeological site Aegae (Aigai) next to Vergina-Central Macedonia, in northern Greece.Â He was a Peripatetic philosopher and emperor Neroâs tutor in Rome.

Alexander of Aphrodisias - á¼Î»Î­Î¾Î±Î½Î´ÏÎ¿Ï á½ á¼ÏÏÎ¿Î´Î¹ÏÎ¹ÎµÏÏ (2nd / 3rd century AD)

Alexander was from Aphrodisias, a small ancient Greek town within historic Caria, in western Asia Minor.Â He lived in Athens and was a head of the Peripatetic school. Of all the commentaries on Aristotleâs works, Alexander is known to have written the better ones.

Alexicrates - á¼Î»ÎµÎ¾Î¹ÎºÏÎ¬ÏÎ·Ï (1st / 2nd century AD)

Alexicrates was a Pythagorean philosopher who lived at the time of Plutarch.

Alexinus â á¼Î»ÎµÎ¾á¿Î½Î¿ÏÂ (4th / 3rd century BC)

Alexinus was born in Elis-á¼®Î»Î¹Ï, an ancient Greek district on the Peloponnese peninsula. He later moved to Olympia-á½Î»Ï Î¼ÏÎ¯Î±, which is in the same region.Â Though his doctrines were not preserved, he became known for writing against Zeno and Ephorus the historian, and criticizing the rhetorical sophists.

Amelius - á¼Î¼Î­Î»Î¹Î¿ (3rd century AD)

Amelius was from Tuscany, Italy.Â Traveling to Rome he became a Neoplatonic student of the philosopher Plotinus. Later in his life, he settled in Syria.Â Amelius was not his original name, rather calling himself Amelius in order to emphasize his thoughts on ephemeral things.Â The word á¼Î¼Î­Î»ÎµÎ¹Î± (ameleia) means negligence in Greek. He wrote extensively and over 100 volumes of sayings and commentaries have been preserved

Ammonius Hermiae â Â á¼Î¼Î¼ÏÎ½Î¹Î¿Ï á½ á¼ÏÎ¼ÎµÎ¯Î¿Ï (5th / 6th century AD)

Ammoniusâ parents were Hermias and Aedesia, Neoplatonist philosophers from Alexandria, who travelled regularly to Athens where they apprenticed and worked; hence, Ammonius lived in Athens and Alexandria. His life work was writing commentaries on Plato, Aristotle and other significant ancient Greek philosophers.Â The lecture notes kept by his students provide an insight on the extent of his work:Â On Aristotleâs Categories (anonymous writer), On Aristotleâs Prior Analytics I (anonymous writer), Â On Aristotleâs Metaphysics 1â7 (written by Asclepius), Â On Nicomachusâ Introduction to Arithmetic (written by Asclepius), On Aristotleâs Prior Analytics (written by John Philoponus), On Aristotleâs Posterior Analytics (written by John Philoponus), On Aristotleâs On Generation and Corruption (written by John Philoponus), On Aristotleâs On the Soul (written by John Philoponus).

Ammonius of Athens - á¼Î¼Î¼ÏÎ½Î¹Î¿Ï (1st century AD)

Ammonius was from Athens, known as Ammonius the Peripatetic.Â He was a Middle Platonist and Plutarchâs teacher.Â From Plutarch, we came to know that Ammonius was an expert in the works of Aristotle.

Ammonius Saccas - á¼Î¼Î¼ÏÎ½Î¹Î¿Ï Î£Î±ÎºÎºá¾¶Ï (2nd / 3rd century AD)

Ammonius was from Alexandria.Â A Greek Philosopher, he is considered as one of the founders of Neoplatonism.Â His life work centered on the soul being immaterial.Â Plotinus, who was his pupil, continued in this theory.

Anaxagoras - á¼Î½Î±Î¾Î±Î³ÏÏÎ±Ï (5th century BC)

Anaxagoras was born in Clazomenae, an ancient Greek city in Asia Minor on the Aegean coastline.Â A Pre-Socratic Greek philosopher, he was the first to bring philosophy and the spirit of scientific inquiry from Ionia to Athens.Â He was a part of the Pluralist School along with Archelaus and Empedocles.Â Learning at this school was centered with the principle of monism.Â Anaxagoras, however, believed that the whole of nature contained an innumerable number of principles.

Anaxarchus - Â á¼Î½Î¬Î¾Î±ÏÏÎ¿Ï (4th century BC)

Anaxarchus was born in Abdera, Thrace, an important coastline city.Â Belonging to the school of Democritus and he promoted the natural philosophy of Atomism.Â Close friend to Alexander the Great, he followed him into the Asian campaigns.Â Little is known about his philosophical views.Â What has prevailed is that his learning was a precursor for Greek Skeptic:Â a mixture of the atomism of Democritus, and the skepticism of Pyrrho.

Anaxilaus â Anaxilas (1st century BC / 1st century AD)

Anaxilas was from Larissa, the capital city of the Thessaly region of Greece.Â A Pythagorean philosopher, he also studied the philosophy of nature and psychics. His learning was primarily dedicated to the study of the properties in minerals and herbs.

Anaximander- á¼Î½Î±Î¾Î¯Î¼Î±Î½Î´ÏÎ¿Ï (7th / 6th century BC)

Anaximander was from Miletus, an ancient Greek city along the coastline of western Asia Minor.Â A Pre-Socratic Philospher, he belonged to the Milesian School of his native city.Â His interests were in science and he learned about the universe, the origins and natural law.Â He spoke of the apeiron (á¼ÏÎµÎ¹ÏÎ¿Î½), which denotes âunlimited,â âinfiniteâ or âindefiniteâ; thus, constituting an arche (á¼ÏÏÎ®) for him.Â His life work is characterized by his metaphysical research.Â Anaximander provided an explanation of how the four elements of ancient physics are formed (air, earth, water and fire).Â By extension, he further explained how Earth and terrestrial beings are formed through their interactions.

Anaximenes of Miletus - á¼Î½Î±Î¾Î¹Î¼Î­Î½Î·Ï (6th century BC)

Anaximenes was from Miletus and belonged to the Miletus School.Â A Pre-Socratic Philosopher and a student of Anaximander, he is known one of the three famous philosophers from Miletus.Â Concentrating on material monism, Anaximenes spoke about archai (á¼ÏÏÎ±Î¯) as being an aer (air), that substance from which all other things are made of. Pursuing this theory about earth, he concluded that air felted to create the flat disk of the earth resulting with earth behaving like a leaf floating on air.

Androcydes â Androkydes (2nd century BC-?)

Androcydes is well-known because of his work on âOn Pythagorean Symbolsâ. Thereâs no evidence about his life, other than his being extensively quoted by other philosophers.

Andronicus of Rhodes- á¼Î½Î´ÏÏÎ½Î¹ÎºÎ¿Ï Î¿ Î¡ÏÎ´Î¹Î¿Ï (1st century BC)

Andronicus was born on Rhodes, the largest island of the Dodecanese Islands of Greece. Â Little is known about him.Â He travelled to Rome where he taught and he was a Scholarch, Head of Peripatetic School.Â His interests lay in the field of the history of philosophy.

Anniceris â á¼Î½Î½Î¯ÎºÎµÏÎ¹Ï (4th / 3rd century BC)

Anniceris lived during the time of Alexander the Great.Â He belonged to the Philosophy of Cyrenaics or Kyrenaics. This school of philosophy, founded by Aristippus of Cyrene, learned about sensual hedonism. Â His life work is characterized by denying that pleasure is merely the absence of pain and that reason â Î»ÏÎ³Î¿Ï alone can save us from errors.

Antiochus of AscalonÂ â ÎÎ½ÏÎ¯Î¿ÏÎ¿Ï á½ á¼ÏÎºÎ±Î»ÏÎ½Î¹Î¿Ï (2nd / 1st century BC)

He was born in Ascalon. His philosophy was a part of Academic School , but at the same time he was influenced by Academic scepticism. Intellectuals feel that with him begins the philosophy of Middle Platonism .

Antipater of Cyrene â á¼Î½ÏÎ¯ÏÎ±ÏÏÎ¿ÏÂ (4th century BC)

Antipater was born in Cyrene in ancient Libya. He lived at the time of the beginig of the Cyreanic School of philosophy.

Antipater of Tarsus - á¼Î½ÏÎ¯ÏÎ±ÏÏÎ¿Ï (2nd century BC)

Antipater was born in Tarsus, the ancient city in Turkey. His philosophical teachings were a part of the Stoic School of Philosophy. He believed in God as a goodwill for all menkind. He wrote two books about this issue. Also, he dealt and with the moral philosophy.

Antipater of Tyre- á¼Î½ÏÎ¯ÏÎ±ÏÏÎ¿Ï á½ Î¤ÏÏÎ¹Î¿Ï (1st century BC)

He was a part of Stoic School of philosophy. He was born in Tyre and died in Athens. His famous works were: Â " On Duties" and " o n the Cosmos".

Antisthenes - á¼Î½ÏÎ¹ÏÎ¸Î­Î½Î·Ï (5th / 4th century BC)

He was born in Athens, but after his childhood he moved to Tanagra. His teacher was Socrates. The most famous source about his philosophy was from papers of Diogenes Laertius. His philosophical work was most in ethics, physics, logic and philosophy of language. Some intellectuals saw him as a founder of Cynics, maybe because his lifestyleÂ wasÂ ascetic.

Antoninus -Â á¼Î½ÏÏÎ½á¿Î½Î¿ÏÂ (4th century AD)

Antoninus was a Greek philosopher born in Egypt where he founded his own philosophical school. His philosophy was a part of Neoplatonic philosophy. Some of his teachings some of intellectuals titled asÂ paganic teachings.

Apollodorus of Athens â á¼ÏÎ¿Î»Î»ÏÎ´ÏÏÎ¿ÏÂ (2nd century BC)

Apollodorus was Athenian philosopher and a son of the famous Ancient Greek historianÂ Asclepiades. He has the most famous teachers of his time such as Diogenes of Babylon. His most famous books are: Chronicle (Î§ÏÎ¿Î½Î¹ÎºÎ¬), On the Gods (Î ÎµÏá½¶ Î¸Îµá¿¶Î½), a twelve-book essay about Homer's Catalogue of Ships, an early etymology with the analyses of the poets Epicharmus of Kos and Sophron, a very few critical and grammatical writings as well asÂ âThe encyclopedia of Greek mythology-Bibliothecaâ.

Apollodorus of Seleucia -Â á¼ÏÎ¿Î»Î»ÏÎ´ÏÏÎ¿Ï (2nd century BC)

Appollodorus was born in Seleucia, the city in ancient Mesopotamia. He was a part of Stoic philosophy and he was an author of several handbooks in the field ofÂ Stoic philosophy, Physics and Ethics. His teacher wasÂ Diogenes of Babylon.

Apollodorus the Epicurean â á¼ÏÎ¿Î»Î»ÏÎ´ÏÏÎ¿Ï (2nd century BC)

He lived in Athens, where he wasÂ the main person of the Epicurean school. He was well-known as a pupil of Zeno of Sidon. He wrote two books: Life of Epicurus and a Collection of Doctrines.

Apollonius Cronus -Â ÎÏÏÎ½Î¿Ï á¼ÏÎ¿Î»Î»ÏÎ½Î¹Î¿Ï (4th century BC)

Apollonuius was born in Cyrene, the city in ancient Libya. His philosophy was a part of the Megarian school. There`s no eveidence about his life exept the fact that his pupils was Diodorus Cronus and Strabo as well as he was a pupil of Eubulides.

Apollonius of Tyana â á¼ÏÎ¿Î»Î»ÏÎ½Î¹Î¿Ï á½ Î¤Ï Î±Î½ÎµÏÏ (1st century AD)

Apollonius was born in Tyana, the city of ancient Anatolia. This philosopher was very interesting because he lived in the thime of Jesus of Nazareth by opinion of many schoolars and he was some kind of âJesus of philosophy of that timeâ. Thanks to Julia Domna, the wife of Roman Emperor Lucius Septimius Severus, which took the request to the philosopher Philostratus to write biography about Apollonius we today know some facts about his life. Some of these facts are that Apollonius had extra-sensory perception. He was inspiration for schoolars over years as well asÂ for writers and novelists around the world.

Apollonius of Tyre â á¼ÏÎ¿Î»Î»ÏÎ½Î¹Î¿Ï (1st century BC)

Apollonius was born in Tyre, the city of ancient Lebanon. By some authors such as Strabo or Diogenes Laertius he was a part of Stoic philosophy, with the high influence of the teachings of Zeno.

Arcesilaus - á¼ÏÎºÎµÏÎ¯Î»Î±Î¿ÏÂ (4th / 3rd century BC)

Arcesilaus was born in Pitane, the ancient Greek Asia Minor. He is well known as a founder of the phase of the Academic Scepticism of Athenian Academy. He was a pupil ofÂ mathematician Autolycus as well as his teacher was and philosopher Theophrastus in the period of his life in Athens where he studied rethoric and philosophy. He hadn`t writings works. What is known is that he writes about teachings of Plato and Cicero. His main oponents were the Stoics philosophers.

Archedemus of Tarsus âÂ ÎÏÏÎ­Î´Î·Î¼Î¿Ï (2nd century BC)

Archedemus was born in Tarsus in ancient Turkey. Today we know about his work thanks to some of authors of the ancient time such as Diogen Laertie, Ciciero, Seneca or Epictetus. By this authors Archedemus was a part of the philosophy of Stoia. His main writings in the field of philosophy are: Î ÎµÏá½¶ Î¦ÏÎ½á¿Ï- On the Voice and Î ÎµÏá½¶ Î£ÏÎ¿Î¹ÏÎµÎ¯ÏÎ½-On Elements.

Archelaus â á¼ÏÏÎ­Î»Î±Î¿Ï (5th century BC)

Archelaus was born in Miletus, but his family was from Athens.Â By the opinion of schoolars he`s well known because he was the teacher of Socrates. His philosophy was a part of Physicus or Ionnian Scool of Philosophy. The teachings of that school were in the field of natural philosophy and he was the first teacher of this discipline in Athens. His teacher was Anaxagoras. There`s no writings of him but there`s well known teachings of him about the the Sun as the largest star in the cosmos. This kind of philosophy is high influenced by his main teacher Anaxagoras.

Archytas - á¼ÏÏÏÏÎ±Ï (5th / 4th century BC)

He was from Tarentum, the city of ancient Magna Grecia. Behind philosophy he dealt and with mathematics, astronomy, strategy, etc. He was well-known as a first mathematician who dealt with the mathematical mechanics. His most famous work was so-called âThe Archytas curveâ . As a philosopher, many of schoolars notice that he was probably rolle-model for a Plato`s learning about king who is philosopher at the same time (the rolle-model of sophocracy ).

Arete of Cyrene â á¼ÏÎ®ÏÎ· (4th century BC)

Arete of Cyrene was a woman philosopher. She was born in Cyrene, the city in ancient Libya. Her father and the teacher at the same time wasÂ Aristippus, pupil of Socrates. She was also teacher to her own son as Greeks say Î¼Î·ÏÏÎ¿Î´Î¯Î´Î±ÎºÏÎ¿Ï. She dealt with the moral and natural philosophy in Attica for a years. She was not only clever, but she was very beautiful woman as historian described her she was âthe beauty of Helensâ .

Arignote - á¼ÏÎ¹Î³Î½ÏÏÎ·Â (6th / 5th century BC)

Arignote was born in Croton, the city in ancient Calabria. She was a woman philosopher and a part of the Pythagorean philosophy. She was a pupil of Pythagoras. There are several writings of she such as: Bacchica (ÎÎ±ÎºÏÎ¹ÎºÎ¬, Bakkhika, "Of Bacchus"), The Mysteries of Demetra (Î ÎµÏá½¶ Ïá¿¶Î½ ÎÎ®Î¼Î·ÏÏÎ¿Ï ÎÏ ÏÏÎ·ÏÎ¯ÏÎ½, Peri ton Demetros Mysterion), A Sacred Discourse (á¼¹ÎµÏá½¸Ï ÎÏÎ³Î¿Ï, Hieros Logos), Mysteries of Dionysus (Î¤ÎµÎ»ÎµÏÎ±á½¶ ÎÎ¹Î¿Î½ÏÏÎ¿Ï , Teletai Dionysou).

Aristarchus of Samos-Â á¼ÏÎ¯ÏÏÎ±ÏÏÎ¿Ï á½ Î£Î¬Î¼Î¹Î¿Ï (c. 310 â c. 230 BC)

He wasn`t only a philosopher but a well-known astronomer and mathematician of the Ancient Greek world. Â His native place was Â an island SamosÂ in the eastern Aegean Sea in Greece. His teachings were the most about heliocentrism. His inspiration was Philolaus of Croton , but his ideas were usually suspicious by Aristotle for example. Today, his statue stands at the Aristotle University of Thessaloniki .

Aristippus -Â á¼ÏÎ¯ÏÏÎ¹ÏÏÎ¿Ï (c. 435 â c. 356 BCE)

He was bor in Ancient Lybia, precisely in Cyrene. He was well-known as a founder of the famous Cyreanic school. His teacher was Socrates . Very interesting detail from his personal life was that his daughter was beautiful woman philosopher Arete. He was an author of theÂ controversial book about the private life of intellectuals of his time entitled " On the Luxury of the Ancients".

Aristippus the Younger-Â á¼ÏÎ¯ÏÏÎ¹ÏÏÎ¿Ï (4th century BC)

He was famous mostly as a grandson of Aeistippus and a son of Arete of Cyrene.Â His nickname was "Mother-taught" - metrodidaktos because he was a pupil of his mother also well-known philosopher. His philosophy was a part of the Cyreanic School .

Aristoclea - ÎÎµÎ¼Î¹ÏÏÏÎºÎ»ÎµÎ¹Î± (fl. 6th century BC)

She was a woman philosoher. Her name was also Themistoclea. At the same time she was a priestess in ancient oracle of Delphi.

Aristocles of Messene-Â á¼ÏÎ¹ÏÏÎ¿ÎºÎ»á¿Ï á½ ÎÎµÏÏÎ®Î½Î¹Î¿Ï Â (1st century AD?)

He was born in ancient Sicily. His pupil wasÂ Alexander of Aphrodisias. He wrote a few works such as: Î ÏÏÎµÏÎ¿Î½ ÏÏÎ¿Ï Î´Î±Î¹ÏÏÎµÏÎ¿Ï á½Î¼Î·ÏÎ¿Ï á¼¢ Î Î»Î¬ÏÏÎ½ - Whether Homer or Plato is more Worthy, Î¤Î­ÏÎ½Î±Î¹ á¿¥Î·ÏÎ¿ÏÎ¹ÎºÎ±Î¯ - Arts of Rhetoric, A work on the god Serapis,Â Ethics (nine books), Philosophy (in ten books) .

Aristocreon-á¼ÏÎ¹ÏÏÎ¿ÎºÏÎ­ÏÎ½ (fl. 200 BC)

He was born and lived in Athens. His philosophy was a part of the Stoic School .Â An interesting detail of his life is that he was a cousin of Chrysippus who was at the same time and his teacher.

Aristo of Alexandria - á¼ÏÎ¯ÏÏÏÎ½ (2nd /1st century BC)

He was born in Alexandria in ancient Egypt. His philosophy was influenced by Strabo and also it was a part of the Peripatetic School.

Aristo of Ceos - á¼ÏÎ¯ÏÏÏÎ½ á½ ÎÎµá¿Î¿Ï (3rd / 2nd century BC)

He was born in the Island of Ceos. He was a part of the Peripatetic School and also was a head of the school about 269 BC.Â There`re doubts about the authenticity of his written works.

Aristo of Chios -Â á¼ÏÎ¯ÏÏÏÎ½ á½ Î§á¿Î¿Ï (fl. c. 260 BC)

He was well-known Stoic philosopher. His philosophy was a backbone of the system of Stoic philosophy but it was very close to Cynic philosophy. Aristo was born in Chios but lived in Athens. He didn`t accept learnings of Zeno about the logic and physic even he was his pupil. Â His the main moments in philosophy are: logic, Â physic and ethics.

ARISTOTLE-á¼ÏÎ¹ÏÏÎ¿ÏÎ­Î»Î·Ï

Aristotle of Cyrene -Â á¼ÏÎ¹ÏÏÎ¿ÏÎ­Î»Î·Ï ( fl. 325 BC)

He was born in Cyrene and he was a part of famous the Cyreanic School. There`re no detailed evidence about his work and life.

Aristotle of Mytilene - á¼ÏÎ¹ÏÏÎ¿ÏÎ­Î»Î·Ï á½ ÎÏ ÏÎ¹Î»Î·Î½Î±á¿Î¿Ï (2nd century AD)

He was a part of the Perpatetic School . He was born in Mytilene and his well-known pupil was Alexander of Aphrodisias.
